items.title:
@tak3sh8 @sainingxie @giffmana SimCLR is an example of Siamese network (look this up). 
There were p...
items.content:
@tak3sh8 @sainingxie @giffmana SimCLR is an example of Siamese network (look this up). 
There were papers in this at NIPS 1993, and CVPR 2005 and 2006 (co-authored by me).
But SimCLR showed that could be made to work at a decent level on ImageNet.

Having ideas is good.
Making them work on small problems is also good.
Making them work on large problems is not easy and should not be dismissed as mere "PR tours".

I know that some folks in our community seem to think that whoever has the a germ of an idea and publishes it in an obscure tech report should get all the credit for everything vaguely related to it that appeared later.
But that's a very perverse idea of how credit assignment should work.
Demonstrating that an idea actually works deserves credit.
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: Yann LeCun argues that demonstrating ideas work at scale deserves credit, not just having early conceptual versions. Pushes back against giving all credit to earliest papers.
items.reasoning: Turing Award winner sharing important perspective on research credit attribution. Philosophically significant for ML community norms. High engagement from credible source.

items.title:
‚ú® After many years, I finally got multi characters working on Photo AI now  ü•≥ü•≥ü•≥

You can now train a...
items.content:
‚ú® After many years, I finally got multi characters working on Photo AI now  ü•≥ü•≥ü•≥

You can now train and then select up to 4 multiple characters (by holding [ ‚áß Shift ] or long pressing on mobile) and they will be generated all together in a single photo

This makes Photo AI much more interesting as a product now because most photos are not of a single person, but of couples, or groups like families (think how much group family photographers charge etc)

This was the #1 most requested feature for years and was never possible because with both Stable Diffusion and Flux, I'd train a LoRa on one character (person), and if I combined multiple LoRas, instead of generating both people it would merge the two people's likeness into one, so absolutely useless. For a long time I tried to think of other ways, like generating one image first with multiple people, then replacing those people with each LoRa with img2img, but it was all too unwieldy and didn't really work well

Couples kinda worked if you'd train a new model with photos of both of you, but every photo had to kinda have the same position like (you left, partner right) or it'd start messing it up, TL;DR the models were too dumb to do this

But with all the new models now like Nano Banana Pro and Hyper Realism, they're finally smart enough to understand what you want to generate

The results are very detailed and you can do stuff like 
1) extreme close ups with cool lights (AI Photography pack)
2) put you and your gf in Berghain (Berlin photo pack)
3) turn you guys into digital nomads in Bangkok (digital nomad pack)

THANK YOU FOR YOUR ATTENTION TO THIS MATTER üòä

items.title: **Navigation World Models** by @ylecun and his colleagues. This CVPR 2025 Best Paper Honorable Menti...
items.content:
**Navigation World Models** by @ylecun and his colleagues. This CVPR 2025 Best Paper Honorable Mention paper extends the "thinking" concept we are used to in LLMs to robot movement planning.

The authors train what they call a "world model"‚Äîa neural network that takes the current camera view and a movement command (like "go forward and turn left"), then predicts what the camera will see afterward.

The model uses diffusion, a technique where you train a network to gradually remove noise from images, which turns out to work well for generating realistic future views. 

The interesting part is how they use this for planning: instead of learning a fixed policy that says "given this goal, take this action," the model simulates many possible movement sequences, checks which one ends up looking most like the goal image, and picks that path. 

This means you can add constraints at test time (like "don't turn left") without retraining. They also show that training on random human walking videos from the internet helps the model generalize to new environments it has never seen, even though those videos have no robot action labels‚Äîthe model just learns visual priors about how indoor and outdoor scenes look when you walk through them.

Read online and ask clarifying questions while reading: https://t.co/mH74YbUrSl

Download the PDF: https://t.co/EEYrsMWnzK
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov summarizes Navigation World Models paper (CVPR 2025 Best Paper Honorable Mention) by LeCun et al. - world model predicts camera views from movement commands using diffusion for robot planning
items.reasoning: Excellent technical summary of award-winning paper. Explains how diffusion enables flexible robot navigation planning. High educational value.

items.title:
One of the first agents I built was extremely simple:

It retrieved information from a vector store,...
items.content:
One of the first agents I built was extremely simple:

It retrieved information from a vector store, formatted it as HTML, and emailed it to the user.

It doesn't get simpler than this, and yet, this agent failed about 1% of the time.

No error. No warning. It just returned garbage.

Here is the harsh truth:

Agents fail a lot. And they fail silently. All the time. You just can't trust an LLM to do the right thing every time.

By now, I've built and deployed a couple of dozen agents, and here are some of the things that actually work:

1. Observability from day one. If you can't see what your agent is doing, you can't debug it, improve it, or trust it. Every agent should produce traces showing the full request flow, model interactions, token usage, and timing metadata.

2. Guardrails on inputs and outputs. Everything that goes into and comes out of an LLM should be checked by deterministic code. Even things that aren't likely to break will eventually break.

3. LLM-as-a-judge evaluation. You can build a simple judge using an LLM to automatically evaluate your agent's outputs. Label a dataset, write the evaluation prompt, and iterate until your judge catches most failures.

4. Error analysis. You can collect failure samples, categorize them, and diagnose the most frequent mistakes.

5. Context engineering. Often, agents fail because their context is noisy, overloaded, or irrelevant. Learning how to keep context relevant is huge.

6. Human feedback loops. Sometimes the best guardrail is a human in the loop, especially for high-stakes decisions.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Svpino shares lessons from building dozens of AI agents: agents fail silently ~1% of the time. Provides 6 key practices: observability from day one, guardrails on inputs/outputs, LLM-as-judge evaluation, error analysis, context engineering, and human feedback loops.
items.reasoning: Highly practical production insights from experienced practitioner, addresses critical reliability issues with LLM agents, high engagement (144 likes, 22K views)

items.title: @loveactuary Good questions. I am usually loath to give too specific advice based on my own experien...
items.content:
@loveactuary Good questions. I am usually loath to give too specific advice based on my own experience because my own experience has been too idiosyncratic and unusual. But here are some of my very general thoughts:

1. A major disruption is coming, but we don't know how ill it play out. I am betting that what comes on the other side will be largely (and enormously) positive. If it were anything else, then all planing is futile in the end.

2. While what awaits us might be extremely beneficial, the transition could be extremely unsettling and chaotic. Try to be as prepared on every level you can for it. Put your affairs in order. Have enough basic resources that could last you a few years. 

3. I don't believe that investing into any kind of skills, "marketable" or "unmarketable" will make that much of a difference for the vast majority of people. That's why I am pretty relaxed about my children's education.

4. I hope to be able to support my children *directly* and *personally* as much as possible though most of their lives. That's one of the reasons why I moved to a relatively affordable area, where I hope my children could also settle. 

5. In terms of investment (and this is NOT an investment advice), I am largely betting on things that will directly benefit from the technological revolution and things that have stood the test of time. I don't want to be any more specific than that. ;)

items.summary: Detailed perspective on preparing for AI disruption: betting on positive outcomes, preparing for chaotic transition, skepticism about skill investment mattering, focus on family support, investment strategy hints
items.reasoning: Thoughtful, substantive original perspective on AI's societal impact from credible Kaggle grandmaster; practical advice framework; unique personal philosophy shared

items.title:
Engineering fundamentals are force multipliers for AI.

If you have tests, AI can run them after eve...
items.content:
Engineering fundamentals are force multipliers for AI.

If you have tests, AI can run them after every change and self-correct. If you don't, you're just hoping nothing breaks.

If you have a CI/CD pipeline, you can deploy AI-generated code with confidence. If you don't, you're just hoping nothing breaks.

If you have a good code review process, you can catch any issues with AI-generated code. If you don't, you're just hoping nothing breaks.

If you have solid documentation, AI will understand your codebase and generate much better code. If you don't, you're just hoping nothing breaks.

The gap between teams with solid software engineering foundations and those without is about to get massive.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Svpino argues that engineering fundamentals (tests, CI/CD, code review, documentation) are force multipliers for AI. Teams with solid foundations can leverage AI-generated code confidently while others just 'hope nothing breaks.'
items.reasoning: Insightful take on intersection of traditional software engineering and AI development, very high engagement (282 likes), practical implications for development teams

items.title: Honestly I think the only realistic solution to the decreasing quality of service in the West is rob...
items.content:
Honestly I think the only realistic solution to the decreasing quality of service in the West is robots

I don't think even if you fix the societal problems of high cost of living (which people say is why people suck at their jobs these days, fair) that anyone will want to do these jobs anymore in the West at least

When ChatGPT 4 was here I already thought it'd do a better job than 99% of people working in service jobs, imagine now

With modern AI models and robotics, I think companies will be able to produce a much much better service experiences than humans

I don't know if it'll be fully automated hotels, restaurants, cafes, airline service staff, or humanoid robots, or something in between

Who wants a grumpy tired human if you can get a friendly humanoid helping you?

Do I prefer the enshittification to stop and instead have humans? Yes I absolutely do ideally but I'm just realistic that I doubt that's going to happen in the West

People doing service jobs in the West hate their jobs, people hate interacting with them because they hate their jobs, and meanwhile robots can do a 10x better job for 1000x cheaper

Inevitable I think

items.title:
One thing that LLM agents can't do well:

Any old-school chatbot can stay on script, while LLM agent...
items.content:
One thing that LLM agents can't do well:

Any old-school chatbot can stay on script, while LLM agents tend to go rogue and lead customers into weird conversations.

But of course, old chatbots feel robotic, and customers don't want to talk to them.

They are reliable, but people don't like them,

LLM agents are the opposite.

They're fluid and adaptive, but they can say anything. You're literally one hallucination away from a disaster.

The guys behind Parlant are doing something really smart with their new version: You can build an agent with the best of both worlds.

The agent can dynamically switch between an LLM agent and strict mode based on what's happening in the conversation.

Risk isn't uniform across a conversation:

1. When a customer asks a casual product question, Parlant engages the LLM to generate a fluid and helpful answer.

2. When a customer asks for a refund, Parlant engages strict mode to only return approved, contextually-driven response templates.

You control the agent's "composition mode" based on natural-language observations about the current state of the conversation.

This is a really cool idea. It should significantly improve the current state of the art in chatbots.

You can check it out here: https://t.co/iaSQPf4fku

The attached diagram shows how the dynamic composition mode works.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Analysis of LLM agent limitations: old chatbots stay on script but feel robotic, LLM agents are fluid but unpredictable. Highlights Parlant's new approach using dynamic composition mode that switches between LLM and strict mode based on conversation risk level.
items.reasoning: Addresses fundamental LLM agent challenge with practical solution, introduces novel hybrid approach (Parlant), good engagement from AI educator

items.title:
What surprised me most is how much of this challenge is cultural.

You can deploy advanced models, b...
items.content:
What surprised me most is how much of this challenge is cultural.

You can deploy advanced models, but unless teams are trained, aligned, and confident, the AI will never reach production scale.

Education is now as important as engineering.

The organizations winning today are the ones that treat AI like a mission critical capability, not a side project.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Observes that AI deployment challenge is largely cultural - teams need training and alignment before AI can scale to production
items.reasoning: Insightful observation about organizational barriers to AI adoption. Education as important as engineering is a key takeaway

items.title:
The biggest myth in industrial AI is that the tech is the problem.

The real issues start long befor...
items.content:
The biggest myth in industrial AI is that the tech is the problem.

The real issues start long before the model ever runs.

We are asking AI to make decisions on top of

‚Üí aging infrastructure
‚Üí fragmented data
‚Üí understaffed and undertrained teams
‚Üí supply chains that break under minimal pressure

If the foundation is unstable, the AI is unstable.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Argues the biggest myth is that tech is the problem - real issues are aging infrastructure, fragmented data, understaffed teams, and brittle supply chains
items.reasoning: Valuable insight challenging common narratives about AI implementation failures. Highlights systemic organizational issues

üì° Today I built a HTTP proxy that lets all the old computers in the world surf the web too

Browsers...
items.content:
üì° Today I built a HTTP proxy that lets all the old computers in the world surf the web too

Browsers from before 2013 don't support modern HTTPS so they literally can't acces any website

That's very sad for all the old cute retro computers who also wanna go on the internet üòû 

So to be inclusive, I vibecoded my own web-based proxy, and it lets them browse HTTPS websites and search Google

Here's how it looks on my physical https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC box that I built by installing a Raspberry Pi 5 into this Checkmate retro display and hooking it up with an 8BitDo keyboard and mouse and dial-up internet connection

Inb4 why, it's fun!!!

You can try it live on https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC in Internet Explorer, I set it as the homepage

items.title:
Safety and security are not features in industrial AI, they are non negotiable.

When precision must...
items.content:
Safety and security are not features in industrial AI, they are non negotiable.

When precision must reach five nines, you cannot rely on experimentation or loose governance. You need:

‚Üí verified data at every decision point
‚Üí airtight operational processes
‚Üí continuous validation inside live environments

Industrial AI is not just smarter automation. It is a discipline.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Emphasizes that safety/security are non-negotiable in industrial AI requiring five nines precision, verified data, and continuous validation
items.reasoning: Important perspective on industrial AI standards and governance requirements. Very low engagement but substantive content

items.title: @SeanPedersen96 There are inventors who patent plenty of inventions that exist only on paper. The ho...
items.content:
@SeanPedersen96 There are inventors who patent plenty of inventions that exist only on paper. The hope is that at least one out of 1000 will be implemented by someone, will actually work, will actually make money, and then you can claim your patent rights.

So, basically it's the same technique as spam: sending millions of emails hoping for a tiny chance that some of them will be read by someone.

items.summary: Burkov compares patent strategy to spam - filing many paper-only inventions hoping one gets implemented

items.title:
@CobotUli @engineer @technologynews I disagree there too.

My first job was stuffing Apple II mother...
items.content:
@CobotUli @engineer @technologynews I disagree there too.

My first job was stuffing Apple II motherboards for my mom who soldered them. She enjoyed her job, took about 30 minutes.

I later got a job working on HP manufacturing line that did the same in 20 seconds, ending my mom‚Äôs job.

This was 1978.

Why is cutting hair any different?

It isn‚Äôt.

Humans will find something else to do. We always do.

The Backstreet Boys‚Äô performance at Sphere was a reminder that when music, immersive tech, and robotics collide, the future feels very present. High energy, iconic sound, and yes‚Ä¶ robots stealing the show.

That momentum carries straight into hashtag#CES this week, where I‚Äôll be diving deeper into what‚Äôs next through interviews on:
‚úÖ Robotics (Cosmos and GR00T Year One) 
‚úÖ Smarter AI for Enterprises
‚úÖ Intelligent Product Lifecycle

From the stage to the show floor, innovation is setting the rhythm for 2026.

Stay tuned as the future of AI, robotics, and intelligent systems takes center stage.

items.content:
I am married to an Iranian/American who grew up in Tehran.

She, and her family, have been hopeful but reserved. She knows how brutal the current regime is. Previous attempts have ended in bloodshed and no change. 

So hard to get their hopes up.

But if this happens places like Los Angeles and Silicon Valley (both have large Iranian populations, almost none of which like the current leaders, which is why they left to move to America) will erupt in celebrations.
